> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io?src=pr). Last update [7c94d81...3fc334b](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/compare/7c94d81c390881643f94d5e3d7d6fb351a445b72...3fc334b0f7f7ff9c0a6c2f14a44b9b0b12e2ad1f?src=pr)
@superdosh @chadcelect Welcome to the community!
Closing!
@zodiac @briankohler
FYI.. if no further activity on this in the next couple of days, I will be closing for inactivity.
@danielzohar if not further activity on this in the next few days, I will close for inactivity.
@r39132 All done. Also got rid of a few unused imports along the way
whoops
thx.. looking now.

I'm seeing this in my example DAG. 

@mistercrunch @bolkedebruin @jlowin Any ideas on what the poison pill means and why I am seeing it?

```
[2016-11-23 12:29:55,312] {models.py:1273} INFO - Executing <Task(PythonOperator): task5> on 2016-09-01 02:00:00
[2016-11-23 12:29:55,341] {base_hook.py:67} INFO - Using connection to: localhost
[2016-11-23 12:30:05,350] {python_operator.py:81} INFO - Done. Returned value was: None
[2016-11-23 12:30:06,832] {jobs.py:2010} WARNING - State of this instance has been externally set to None. Taking the poison pill. So long.
```

@danielzohar interesting.. tests are failing. I wonder if this is related to the poison pill messages I am seeing as well. Please fix.

```
root: INFO: Executing <Task(PostgresOperator): postgres_operator_test_vacuum> on 2015-01-01 00:00:00
root: INFO: Executing: VACUUM ANALYZE;
root: INFO: Using connection to: localhost
root: INFO: VACUUM ANALYZE;
root: ERROR: VACUUM cannot run inside a transaction block
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/travis/build/apache/incubator-airflow/airflow/models.py", line 1299, in run
    result = task_copy.execute(context=context)
  File "/home/travis/build/apache/incubator-airflow/airflow/operators/postgres_operator.py", line 53, in execute
    self.hook.run(self.sql, self.autocommit, parameters=self.parameters)
  File "/home/travis/build/apache/incubator-airflow/airflow/hooks/dbapi_hook.py", line 171, in run
    cur.execute(s)
InternalError: VACUUM cannot run inside a transaction block

root: INFO: Marking task as FAILED.
root: ERROR: VACUUM cannot run inside a transaction block
```
oh, silly me. That's the reason I created the PR in the first place! I set `autocommit=True` and it should be passing now! @r39132
See https://www.postgresql.org/message-id/20050506215248.E1711@bacon
I plan to work on this this weekend. If not by end of weekend, close this PR, because I can always generate a new one from same branch. The context is clear.
Green!
I'll see if I can find some time over Thanksgiving.
Nice.. retesting locally!

It looks like there is a side-effect of this change in that the `poison pill` line is emitted at the end of dag runs! I need to understand what this means a little better before merging. 

```
[2016-11-23 16:50:20,377] {models.py:1273} INFO - Executing <Task(PythonOperator): task5> on 2016-09-01 00:00:00
[2016-11-23 16:50:20,404] {base_hook.py:67} INFO - Using connection to: localhost
[2016-11-23 16:50:30,412] {python_operator.py:81} INFO - Done. Returned value was: None
[2016-11-23 16:50:35,185] {jobs.py:2010} WARNING - State of this instance has been externally set to None. Taking the poison pill. So long.
```
@mistercrunch @bolkedebruin is this poison pill line innocuous?
@dennisobrien I am looking for someone way to test this. How are you currently using this config and this feature today? What happens if you run `airflow webserver -d`

I'll get back to you on Monday about this.  Thanks for the notes and the questions.  I'll do what I can to make sure there is testing done for each of the cases.
+1 Thx Kengo!

Hi @AndreiDev is this still valid? If yes, then please rebase it with master and resolve conflicts. Also the commit msg has to be changed according to contributor's guide available [here](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/Contributors%27+Guide).

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io?src=pr). Last update [7f0bf57...fda522b](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/compare/7f0bf577bb07fea6b9a9b975e3316be7e1de0e7c...fda522bc52a99e9628ffa38068a867087fe470de?src=pr)

@r39132 : I made an attempt over the weekend to figure things out, but ran into issues, never worked with flask_admin before and didn't have time to dive into it. Also I don't think that changing the http_default is necessary a good idea to 'update' this, because some organizations might have changed this after install. Please make the decision to close the PR, specifying in the JIRA what needs to be done to do this properly. I need more time and knowledge about alembic + flask to finish this and this month looks busy (+ holiday).
I don't like to poison pill thing. It means the state of the Taks has changed while it is at the executor. Will need to dive in to understand.

@bolkedebruin Thanks for working on this and getting this across the line. Strictly speaking, we do require a +1 from another committer before merging new functionality - exceptions being hotfixes/reversions.
@r39132 absolutely right, I thought I had one after the many discussions on this, but that wasn't the case.
@aedoran are you planning to complete this ? I need to add JiraOperator along with JiraSensor for my use case and I wonder if I should pick up on this jira to submit my work.

@jhsenjaliya since this was closed for inactivity, you are welcome to take the submitters' code, add your own, open a fresh PR and submit it for PR review under your name.  In the end, we will want the submitter to respond to feedback and make any necessary changes needed.

@gtoonstra I get your point that changing `http_default` may break airflow for users that have already changed it to point to a custom endpoint if those users use that connection name for some airflow critical work. With that in mind, change the name of the http connection in your PR (e.g. to something like `http_for_example_dag`) and I'll be happy to merge it. 

In general, it was a bad design IMHO to "seed" default connections when they could be used by tests and non-tests alike. It would have been better to explicitly suffix their names with `for_example_dags`.

@r39132 : Ok, had to deal with a merge conflict, but now it should all be there. Created a testing endpoint in views.py, fought with CSRF exemption and the DAG now runs. No alembic, because I don't think that 'static data' is migrated through alembic, only data structures... and this example is probably mostly for new users of airflow who want to play around with the functionalities.

You probably want to add the index definition to the model as well. Example here:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/models.py#L737
@gtoonstra Travis CI is backed up on master.. please run on your fork and post the status here.. after making the requested changes.
@vijaysbhat Really like this idea! I will try to get time to review this later today. Including other committers as well. @bolkedebruin @jlowin @criccomini
@mistercrunch please have a second look

Not sure how to run Travis on my own fork... Can we wait for this to finish and work out the results tomorrow morning?  I prefer to for example remove the comments that are not established code and get this thing finished. At the same time, if you feel it's inappropriate to merge, then I can grab this PR and resubmit for another version, taking in all the comments and make it much better next time.

This has operational consequences which I can not fully oversee. Such as the scheduling now might be biased towards one dag (ie. do other dags run at all?). While this issue is already there it might become more prevalent because of this.

Can you supply operational metrics @vijaysbhat ?

@gtoonstra You could click on the Travis link above or https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-airflow/builds/179855224. On the left-hand side, you can add your own forks / repositories. That way, you can get travis to pass on your fork.. on master, your PR is not even scheduled to run.

My advice is to go ahead and submit updates to this PR asap and let Travis on master pick it up during your nighttime.

@r39132 : Ok, I replaced the commented code with a comment in the end. Waiting for travis to run again, I added my repo, but still need to do some extra work and don't have time for that this very moment.

Dear Airflow team.

I'm not familiar with alembic and SQL and actually failed to generate migration for this PR:
```
$ airflow resetdb
$ alembic -c alembic.ini revision --autogenerate -m "Add id column for task_fails table"
INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Context impl PostgresqlImpl.
INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Will assume transactional DDL.
ERROR [alembic.util.messaging] Target database is not up to date.
  FAILED: Target database is not up to date.
```

Could you please help with that part?

This is why we need a correct foreignkey for dag runs

Please follow https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/Contributors%27+Guide

You need a JIRA to reference this.. and it needs to be in your commit message. I can do that this time for expediency.. but please follow the wiki.
Okay, will do next time - thanks!

@r39132 - Sorry for the delay.  To answer your question, I'm having a hard time testing the changes in this PR.  I don't know if it is my build/install/test setup or if master is not stable at the moment.

I have two ways I'm testing this.
1. Building a docker container with airflow built from my github commit.
    - I'm not testing that this fixes the bug, just that it does not introduce new bugs.
    - There are some problems with basic functionality that I think are bugs in master (but could be a problem in my setup).
2. Building and installing from this github commit on an AWS EC2 behind an ELB.
    - I can verify that https redirects stay https.  This fixes the original problem.
    - But I'm seeing the same problems with master that are breaking the UI and preventing any DAGs from starting.

If it's helpful at all, I created a github repo for running airflow as four separate components as well as redis and mysql using docker and docker-compose.
https://github.com/dennisobrien/airflow-docker-compose-example

The `Dockerfile` has a section for building from the official release in PyPI, or from a github commit.

- These succeed:
    - pip installing 1.7.1.3 from PyPI
    - Building/installing 1.7.1.3 from github source
- These have problems (broken gui, jobs don't trigger)
    - Building/installing from recent master has issues
    - Building/installing from my feature branch

I'm not sure how to proceed here.  I don't feel confident that my PR has no regressions.  I could try finding a recent master that is stable, play my commits on it, build and test from that.

Any other thoughts are much appreciated.

thanks,
Dennis

@bolkedebruin what operational metrics are you looking for? Is there a reference workload I can run it against to get before / after metrics?

Inspecting the code, the task scheduling from the queue happens here - https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/executors/base_executor.py#L98-L101. The queue is sorted by priority, but within a priority the order is undefined. One option is to add the execution date as a secondary sort key so DAGs of the same priority don't resource starve one another. Thoughts?

@gtoonstra Ok, in the midst of this long PR, I forgot my original issue with calling initdb. Your solution still depends on having initdb run and no one is expected to run initdb as part of an upgrade. I understand your concern with creating an alembic migration to add a record to the table.  If you like, I can write it for you and it can be part of this PR. 

You'd need to grant me permission to your fork however.

@vijaysbhat I think that very reasonable. Locally, we see the issue already popping up (workers being saturated with recent runs), so this change would be welcome.

With operational metrics I mean in this case scheduler round trip times, time for a task to become scheduled, time for a dagrun (ie. all tasks) to finish.

Permission granted, thanks for jumping in to get this closed. 

I haven't seen static data being part of alembic upgrades until now. I figured that the examples are mostly useful after a first installation of airflow where initdb gets called, not when there's a production installation that's running that will be used for the purposes of research into the HTTP operator.

I don't think this is the right approach. task_id, dag_id, execution_date is considered to be unique although I understand in this case it isn't. However the right fix would be to have a unique id in the task table and refer to that. This would lead to more model updates obviously (using a proper foreign key with dag runs which would need to be cascaded).

To be honest I dont understand why we have a task_fail table at all, @mistercrunch @r39132 ?

@btallman please rebase if you don't mind (just merged your other PR sorry :) )

@aoen @mistercrunch would you mind taking a look at this?
Why not put the creation of the connection in the example itself? We support this at the moment. I agree this should not be part of the migration scripts.

This is great!

I think something like dag.only_run_latest is a little easier to understand than dag.backfill (which is an overloaded term).

The documentation should also be updated in this PR with this new option in the same PR.

BTW, I just did a bisect and found this commit broke master:  fdb7e949140b735b8554ae5b22ad752e86f6ebaf

For each commit to master I built/installed Airflow with pip.  E.g.,
```
pip install -e git://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow.git@835bcb6234956445d819ff39a5790f635c201c5d#egg=airflow[celery,crypto,hive,jdbc,ldap,password,postgres,s3,vertica]
```
This is building/installing in Docker with Python 3.5.

Previous to this commit, I could pip install and things would work as expected.  After this the on/off buttons do not appear next to the DAGs and not jobs are scheduled.

I'll file a separate ticket for this.

And I'll look into rebasing my PR on the previous working commit 835bcb6234956445d819ff39a5790f635c201c5d to test this.

thanks,
Dennis
Filed this ticket:  https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-664
my design for Jira Operator is different and has more depth & detail, I will assign ticket to myself and will submit new patch, Thanks !

@btallman can you rebase, the I'll be happy to merge. I hope we have covered all corner cases ;-). Please indeed update the documentation and maybe explain there what is the difference between only_run_latest
That would work.
@bolkedebruin Any further thoughts here?

Please read up on how airflow handles schedules. Airflow starts running at the end of each interval by design. Your cron reads "At 00 minutes past every hour", so the interval is hourly, the first interval will be start_date + 1 hour as expected.
Please add a unit test! Thanks.
That is pretty counter-intuitive to anyone used to cron.  Perhaps I missed it elsewhere but is this feature documented anywhere besides the FAQ?

This overload new meaning into the term `backfill`. Let's clarify some of the semantics here.

**backfill**: "a manually triggered CLI process to run or re-run task instances in the past"
**scheduler catchup** (new term): when the scheduler has task instances to run in the past. This assumes a range of dates between tasks' `start_date` and the current date, and active DagRuns in between.

I'd suggest renaming `DAG.backfill` to `allow_scheduler_catchup`.
